awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Automatic mood tracker that analyzes facial expressions and emotions  against social media activity during social media engagement
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an accurate mood detection technology to address social media impacts on young adult patients' mental health. According to the National Institute of Mental Health, young adults aged 18-25 years had a higher incidence of mental illness (29.4%) compared to adults aged 26-49 years (25%) and those aged 50 and older (14.1%).  The proposed technology will focus on facial recognition and facial expression to track emotions using a software application. Non-contact sensors used to detect mood decline may have significant application to health and wellness.  In addition, enabling biometrics such as facial recognition and facial expressions may have significant impact on education, marketing, and surveillance. The proposed technology may address the problem for both the practitioners and their patients and provide a tool for impacting wellness and treatment.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an automatic mood tracker that analyzes facial expressions and emotions during social media engagement. The proposed software accesses the end-users webcam (with their permission) and uses emotion artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms to analyze facial micro-expressions.  When a neutral or negative expression is emoted, the software captures screenshots of social media content and saves it onto the user’s dashboard for self-reflection. In addition, the user’s emotions are analyzed in real time using facial expressions and averaged on the user’s dashboard as an emotional score for their daily mood.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project is to establish the feasibility of ShuffleMe as an early intervention, early detection tool benefiting psychological and physiological state in real-time. Based on customer discovery, we traveled to conferences and performed tabling to determine demand for remote early intervention opportunities in mental health.

In academia, the tool serves as a data analysis tool to interpret real-time social media posts for current mood-state of the poster or reader. Through this project we have also explored passive markers for online cognitive behaviors, and the suitability of computer vision methods to extract psychophysiological responses, in real-time.

The project identified several use-cases in need of a solution to address a problem, especially within commercialization opportunities. The customer discovery activities which identified demand for this type of tool within human resource departments interested in managing mental health of their workforce will now lead to improvement opportunities for ShuffleMe in terms of commercialization purposes. 

The primary result of this project is the identification of a commercialization strategy that focuses on selling ShuffleMe, or future technology derived from it, to larger organizations who could deploy it at scale to their workforce. This is in contrast to the direct to consumer model of offering ShuffleMe as a user-deployed system for tracking one's own mental health during engagement with social media.


Last Modified: 03/30/2023
Modified by: Gregory F Lewis
